"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. The adjacent portion of the Middle Rio Grande provides water to many people in New Mexico. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. It provides water to many people in the State of New Mexico. The bosque should be maintained to protect endangered species, the flow of the river, and be more accessible to the public. Environmental restoration is a key mission of the Corps of Engineers. The State of New Mexico aims to protect the Middle Rio Grande bosque, ensure the flow of the river, and make it more accessible to the public. Environmental restoration is a priority for the Corps of Engineers, who also seek to reestablish hydrologic connections for healthy vegetation growth in the bosque. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Critical restoration project: Immediate and substantial ecosystem restoration, preservation, recreation, and protection benefits.

Middle Rio Grande: Portion of the Rio Grande from Cochiti Dam to Elephant Butte Dam in New Mexico.

Secretary: Secretary of the Army.

SEC. 3. MIDDLE RIO GRANDE RESTORATION. The Secretary will implement critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing studies and plans. Local participation is encouraged in carrying out the Act. The Secretary will utilize existing studies and plans to identify needs for critical restoration projects in the Rio Grande watershed. Local participation from public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration, including the Middle Rio Grande Endangered Species Act Collaborative Program, will be considered. (c) Local Participation.--The Secretary will consult with public and private entities involved in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed, including the Middle Rio Grande Endangered Species Act Collaborative Program and the Bosque Improvement Group of the Middle Rio Grande Bosque Initiative. (d) Cost Sharing.--Before starting any critical restoration project, the Secretary will enter into a cost-sharing agreement with non-Federal interests. Before carrying out critical restoration projects, the Secretary will enter into a cost-sharing agreement with non-Federal interests, requiring them to pay 25% of the total project costs and provide necessary land and materials. Non-Federal interests must pay 25% of total costs, provide land and materials, and cover all future operation and maintenance expenses for critical restoration projects. Non-Federal interests are required to cover 100% of the costs for operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, and rehabilitation of critical restoration projects, and hold the United States harmless from any claims or damages, except for negligence by the Federal Government or its contractors. Non-Federal interests must cover all costs for critical restoration projects and indemnify the United States, excluding negligence. Recreational features in projects cannot exceed 30% of total costs. Non-Federal interests must cover all costs for critical restoration projects, with recreational features limited to 30% of total project cost. Any additional costs for recreational features must be paid by non-Federal interests. Non-Federal interests are responsible for all costs of critical restoration projects, with recreational features limited to 30% of the total project cost. Any extra costs for recreational features exceeding this limit must be covered by the non-Federal interests. Additionally, non-Federal interests can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if the work they perform is deemed integral to the project by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
